Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of Microsecond Time-Resolved Mass Spectrometry for the Study of Biochemical Reaction Mechanisms and Kinetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program of the Division of Chemistry supports work by Professor Hao Chen at Ohio University for the development of microsecond time-resolved mass spectrometry based on ionization of a flying liquid jet generated from ultrafast mixing of reactant solutions by an ambient ionization method. The proposed method is expected to improve sampling resolution from current millisecond sampling to micro-second time resolution. The sucessful development of the described technology will facilitate the investigation of kinetics and mechanisms of fast biochemical reactions, which may lead to a better understanding of protein folding/unfolding, enzymatic catalysis and protein/DNA oxidation processes.

The work provides research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students, including members of underrepresented and disadvantaged groups. Dr. Chen is also actively involved in educational outreach activities, including ChemShows/Workshops/Seminars for pre-college students to learn about modern instrumental analysis and to develop enthusiasm for scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

With this NSF support, we made many contributions to the field of mass spectrometry, including the fundamental study in reaction mechanisms and kinetics as well as the development of novel EC/MS and LC/MS instruments for protein structural analysis and trace chemical analysis. In particular, we successfully developed time-resolved DESI-MS method for measuring fast enzymatic reaction kinetics (Anal. Chem., 2017, 89, 2338–2344), a topic that was not well studied before. In the past 5 years, with this Career Award support, we published 35 articles in peer reviewed journals such as JACS, Angwandte Chemie, Analytical Chemistry and Journal of American Society for Mass Spectrometry.  The published work is accessible from SciFinder or Web of Science. In addition, five PhD dissertations were yielded from this NSF support, which can be downloaded for free from OhioLINK’s Electronic Theses and Dissertations Center.

Our research activities involved five visiting professors/scholars, six graduate and twenty undergraduate students. They were not only introduced to MS, but also learned about ion chemistry, electrochemistry, and bioanalysis. These scholars and students were encouraged to write manuscripts and to give oral or poster presentations in local, regional and national conferences such as ACS, ASMS, MUACC, Lake Arrowhead Ion Chemistry Meeting and Ohio Valley MS Symposium. Each of my PhD students (four female and one male students) supported under this NSF Award published more than 5 papers in peer-reviewed journals. Two graduate students won the Department Research Award, ASMS Postdoc Award and Merck Technology Collaboration Award. Two undergrads involved in this project won the ACS Undergraduate Analytical Chemistry Award and Undergraduate ACS Lavallee Award.

Broader impact of this project also included: i) expanding outreach activities conducted in the local schools by providing ChemShows and tours for pre-college students to learn about modern instrumental analysis and to develop enthusiasm for scientific research; ii) increasing access to the state-of-art equipment for under-represented groups (e.g., students from economically depressed Appalachia region at Ohio university and female student researchers in the PI’s laboratory) and  iii) diversifying the research field and improving the infrastructure of Ohio University’s Center for Intelligent Chemical Instrumentation (CICI), one university initiative to support educating a large population of chemistry major students in our department through laboratory work.
